snippet.textDisplay:
NOTE: some misinformed people are recommending i call the video “people with autism” to be more respectful but i reached out to the autistic community and “autistic people” is heavily preferred. please listen to the community before spreading potentially incorrect* information.
ORIGINAL POST: come back next week for I spent a day with 911 EMERGENCY DISPATCHERS -- thank you so much for supporting me and this series :)
luv, anthony padildo
ps: shoutout to everyone who has turned on notifications 🔔 and directly support me in continuing this series.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you so much Anthony. As an autistic person you don't know how much it means for me to see you treat us as equals. I have been treated like a baby, an idiot, or even like I am not human being so much in my lifetime. To see you respect us and try to understand makes me happy. I am glad you gave us a platform to speak, not a lot of people let us speak for ourselves. I would also like people to know not to support Autism Speaks (search autism speaks controversy to see why), and instead support other groups such as the Autistic Self Advocacy Network who help by providing resources and programs for people on the spectrum.
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you so much Anthony. As an autistic person you don't know how much it means for me to see you treat us as equals. I have been treated like a baby, an idiot, or even like I am not human being so much in my lifetime. To see you respect us and try to understand makes me happy. I am glad you gave us a platform to speak, not a lot of people let us speak for ourselves. I would also like people to know not to support Autism Speaks (search autism speaks controversy to see why), and instead support other groups such as the Autistic Self Advocacy Network who help by providing resources and programs for people on the spectrum.

snippet.textDisplay: The video was great and insightful. But I think it is important to mention that the people interviewed here are all high functioning. Autism is a spectrum and people suffering from more severe form of autism often experience a lot of self harm, severe anxiety and more hindering symptoms and are actually suffering a lot.  In that case I think it is still important to do research and find ways to alleviate those symptoms for better quality of life.
snippet.textOriginal: The video was great and insightful. But I think it is important to mention that the people interviewed here are all high functioning. Autism is a spectrum and people suffering from more severe form of autism often experience a lot of self harm, severe anxiety and more hindering symptoms and are actually suffering a lot.  In that case I think it is still important to do research and find ways to alleviate those symptoms for better quality of life.

snippet.textDisplay: I wish people would treat me differently when they find out I'm autistic--I require a different communication style. If you make a lot of veiled, indirect comments and you read a bunch into the straightforward, direct things I'm saying then we aren't going to understand each other at all. It even happens with healthcare providers, like a lot.
snippet.textOriginal: I wish people would treat me differently when they find out I'm autistic--I require a different communication style. If you make a lot of veiled, indirect comments and you read a bunch into the straightforward, direct things I'm saying then we aren't going to understand each other at all. It even happens with healthcare providers, like a lot.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey Anthony. I appreciate you doing this series. If you need ideas here’s some topics I recommend :)

- People with ADD/ADHD
- People who have to endure mental illnesses
- People with Service Dogs! (My mom has a service dog, and she is a Type 1 Diabetic. The battle between REAL service dogs and FAKE service dogs is real. You could also include that Emotional Support Animals are also okay).
- Type 1 Diabetics (people still get them confused with Type 2 diabetes. Don’t get me wrong, this diabetes is also a major battle. But so many people are misinformed about Type 1 diabetes).
snippet.textOriginal:
Hey Anthony.  I appreciate you doing this series.  If you need ideas here’s some topics I recommend :)

- People with ADD/ADHD
- People who have to endure mental illnesses
- People with Service Dogs! (My mom has a service dog, and she is a Type 1 Diabetic.  The battle between REAL service dogs and FAKE service dogs is real.  You could also include that Emotional Support Animals are also okay).
- Type 1 Diabetics (people still get them confused with Type 2 diabetes.  Don’t get me wrong, this diabetes is also a major battle.  But so many people are misinformed about Type 1 diabetes).

snippet.textDisplay:
I know there’s still tons of learning that needs to be done with autism and the spectrum. There’s still some points of view that consider having ADD or ADHD as being on the autism spectrum.
I have ADD. And I know that having a hard time looking people in the eye is, or could be, a sign of autism.

And I definitely have a hard time looking at people in the eye. It’s just one of the things I’ve wondered.
snippet.textOriginal:
I know there’s still tons of learning that needs to be done with autism and the spectrum.  There’s still some points of view that consider having ADD or ADHD as being on the autism spectrum.
I have ADD.  And I know that having a hard time looking people in the eye is, or could be, a sign of autism.  

And I definitely have a hard time looking at people in the eye.  It’s just one of the things I’ve wondered.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you so much Anthony!!! Finally someone who actually listens to us (autistics) and doesn't hate on us or is being ableistic.
The world has so many stupid misconceptions about autism and it's often used as an insult.
Thank you for helping us to make people accept autism so that we can create a world in which we can be proud to be who we are!
#REDINSTEAD
#DIFFERENTNOTLESS

(If anyone wants to know what living as an autistic is like, just look for the hashtack #actuallyautistic)
snippet.textOriginal:
Thank you so much Anthony!!! Finally someone who actually listens to us (autistics) and doesn't hate on us or is being ableistic. 
The world has so many stupid misconceptions about autism and it's often used as an insult.
Thank you for helping us to make people accept autism so that we can create a world in which we can be proud to be who we are! 
#REDINSTEAD
#DIFFERENTNOTLESS

(If anyone wants to know what living as an autistic is like, just look for the hashtack #actuallyautistic)

snippet.textDisplay: Autistic people shouldn’t really be treated a “Different” People. Being autistic is not a bad thing at all and I feel like people should see autistic people as normal people who are just like us. It’s not like they are entirely the same but they aren’t so different either. In the end we are all human and we should all be blessed that we exist no matter what labels you have as a person.
snippet.textOriginal: Autistic people shouldn’t really be treated a “Different” People. Being autistic is not a bad thing at all and I feel like people should see autistic people as normal people who are just like us. It’s not like they are entirely the same but they aren’t so different either. In the end we are all human and we should all be blessed that we exist no matter what labels you have as a person.

snippet.textDisplay: I myself have autism and was very lucky in the fact that I was diagnosed at the age of six. Many people only find out later in life which can make getting help a harder adjustment. Since I was constantly having sensory overloads, it would cause me to be impatient angry and unfiltered and I would hit scream kick cry and have full on hellish tantrums when I didn’t get what I wanted or I felt misunderstood. This is absolutely not the case for everyone but sadly it was for me and my family and myself had to deal with the consequences. I can’t remember what age but sometime around when I was eight I believe, I started going to a therapist with my mother to help improve my behaviour. The lady that was assigned to us was horrid. I don’t mean to say she only did a bad job, she was an awful person to me. She would say that ‘I was ruining my wonderful mother’s life’, that ‘I was abusing her’ which in a way I was but she told me that I was an awful person and didn’t deserve my mother and how after all she did for me I was being an ungrateful demon. Every time we went, which was weekly, I would cry and scream because I didn’t want to return to her and feel like I was a parasite to my loved ones lives. One time even, when we were driving there, I had opened the car door while we were on the road because I dreaded going so much. One of the worst aspects was that she would do this in front of my mother who was crying too. She had broken me down so much and never built me back up. I later years later found out that this lady never even believed I had autism. I am still young and unlike the people in this video find autism to be a grand burden but I am also grateful for the unique outlook and special qualities that come with having autism. For anyone dealing with any mental health issues, know that you are loved by others who can relate and that there are people who though they don’t know exactly what you are going through, can feel the same way you do. 😊💕✍🏻
snippet.textOriginal: I myself have autism and was very lucky in the fact that I was diagnosed at the age of six. Many people only find out later in life which can make getting help a harder adjustment. Since I was constantly having sensory overloads, it would cause me to be impatient angry and unfiltered and I would hit scream kick cry and have full on hellish tantrums when I didn’t get what I wanted or I felt misunderstood. This is absolutely not the case for everyone but sadly it was for me and my family and myself had to deal with the consequences. I can’t remember what age but sometime around when I was eight I believe, I started going to a therapist with my mother to help improve my behaviour. The lady that was assigned to us was horrid. I don’t mean to say she only did a bad job, she was an awful person to me. She would say that ‘I was ruining my wonderful mother’s life’, that ‘I was abusing her’ which in a way I was but she told me that I was an awful person and didn’t deserve my mother and how after all she did for me I was being an ungrateful demon. Every time we went, which was weekly, I would cry and scream because I didn’t want to return to her and feel like I was a parasite to my loved ones lives. One time even, when we were driving there, I had opened the car door while we were on the road because I dreaded going so much. One of the worst aspects was that she would do this in front of my mother who was crying too. She had broken me down so much and never built me back up. I later years later found out that this lady never even believed I had autism. I am still young and unlike the people in this video find autism to be a grand burden but I am also grateful for the unique outlook and special qualities that come with having autism. For anyone dealing with any mental health issues, know that you are loved by others who can relate and that there are people who though they don’t know exactly what you are going through, can feel the same way you do. 😊💕✍🏻

snippet.textDisplay:
Autistic guy here, cool interview :) If I could say one thing about Autism on such a huge platform, it's: yes, do treat us like normal people. But please have a little extra bit of patience with us. Part of the problem with Autism and especially 'high functioning' Autism or Asperger's, is we seem quite normal on the surface. But that can give a false impression we're just like neurotypicals - quite often we're trying very hard to appear socially 'normal' and it takes a lot of effort, we can mess up easily and make faux passes and accidentally offend people etc, so please just be understanding.

If I can add one other thing, it's that Autism is not a mental disability as the video said. It's a neurobiological disorder. The difference is in the wording - disability is the lack of an ability; it is usually something considered not right, e.g. being blind. Disorder = something out of the ordinary - our brains are just wired different; that is not 'wrong' in its own right. It has only ever been a problem for me when contrasting myself against neurotypicals' societal expectations, which I often fail to live up to.
snippet.textOriginal:
Autistic guy here, cool interview :) If I could say one thing about Autism on such a huge platform, it's: yes, do treat us like normal people. But please have a little extra bit of patience with us. Part of the problem with Autism and especially 'high functioning' Autism or Asperger's, is we seem quite normal on the surface. But that can give a false impression we're just like neurotypicals - quite often we're trying very hard to appear socially 'normal' and it takes a lot of effort, we can mess up easily and make faux passes and accidentally offend people etc, so please just be understanding.

If I can add one other thing, it's that Autism is not a mental disability as the video said. It's a neurobiological disorder. The difference is in the wording - disability is the lack of an ability; it is usually something considered not right, e.g. being blind. Disorder = something out of the ordinary - our brains are just wired different; that is not 'wrong' in its own right. It has only ever been a problem for me when contrasting myself against neurotypicals' societal expectations, which I often fail to live up to.

snippet.textDisplay:
as an autistic person myself, it truly shouldn’t be seen as a disability and a honestly hate the autism vaccination things and it just really makes me feel shitty like autism is something to be looked down upon while we are literally like everyone else, we just think outside the box, we can be very creative and can just be really brought in by simple things (at least in my case) like a rubik’s cube, someone who doesn’t have autism would be less likely to just start it out of the blue, like learn it and everything, they would have to be lured in a sense we just think something and yeah thats happening
im going off my experience alone, everyones autism is different and each one will be thinking different

snippet.textDisplay:
For me, I never saw a problem with having autism. It was just putting a name to something i already had. It's a little frustrating misunderstanding people's words sometimes, and being sensitive to lights and sounds, but it also means that I can find people's missing phones and find small details in things.

Like they said in the video, it's really just our brains running too fast to keep up, like when you have a bunch of tabs open on a computer and your browser runs slower
snippet.textOriginal:

It's a little frustrating misunderstanding people's words sometimes, and being sensitive to lights and sounds, but it also means that I can find people's missing phones and find small details in things. 

Like they said in the video, it's really just our brains running too fast to keep up, like when you have a bunch of tabs open on a computer and your browser runs slower

snippet.textDisplay: My sister has autism. She is not as high functioning as the people in the video, but she can say basic things and do what you tell her to. Sometimes she'll be all hyper and burst out into random laughter, and then other times she'll just sit and stare into no where for the longest. I just want to know so bad what is going on in her brain. Like what is she thinking about that could be so funny, or so serious. It's really wild to think about.

snippet.textDisplay: I have autism, and personally, I think that having it is a gift. I am a LOT more creative than a lot of people my age and intellectual range. I’m not being “bow down to me” in anyway, but I think that it’s not something we should try to go bullshit crazy on it like it’s as bad a psychosis or OCD, but not overlook it like anxiety or paranoia.
snippet.textOriginal: I have autism, and personally, I think that having it is a gift. I am a LOT more creative than a lot of people my age and intellectual range. I’m not being “bow down to me” in anyway, but I think that it’s not something we should try to go bullshit crazy on it like it’s as bad a psychosis or OCD, but not overlook it like anxiety or paranoia.

snippet.textDisplay:
EDIT: Before any of you get in to reading my paragraphs regarding my experience, I would just like to say THANK YOU SO MUCH for making this video! Autism needs to be more understood, it can be a great thing with support from peers!

9:26 If I were asked this, I would say yes. My mom still has me on an IEP for being able to ask to leave the room for a break, which I have never used at all. I thought I was finally off my IEP forever, but I guess not...either way, if I need a break, I will just ask for the bathroom! 2 years ago I basically said to the IEP teacher that I didn't need one anymore, and yet I still have it. I atleast have the option to never use it...
Because I know some people might not know what an IEP is, it's and Independent Education Program. It is for when kids have specific needs that aren't necessarily allowed in school. It's not just for mental disorders either, I have scoliosis and before I went to a non-uniform school I had to have being able to wear non-uniform pants on my IEP so my brace wouldn't push my pants down. Somehow, it took kids in my elementary school (I was allowed to wear other pants in kindergarten) all the way through elementary (5th grade) to notice I wasn't wearing the correct pants, haha!
Thanks for reading :D
snippet.textOriginal:
EDIT: Before any of you get in to reading my paragraphs regarding my experience, I would just like to say THANK YOU SO MUCH for making this video! Autism needs to be more understood, it can be a great thing with support from peers!

9:26 If I were asked this, I would say yes. My mom still has me on an IEP for being able to ask to leave the room for a break, which I have never used at all. I thought I was finally off my IEP forever, but I guess not...either way, if I need a break, I will just ask for the bathroom! 2 years ago I basically said to the IEP teacher that I didn't need one anymore, and yet I still have it. I atleast have the option to never use it...
Because I know some people might not know what an IEP is, it's and Independent Education Program. It is for when kids have specific needs that aren't necessarily allowed in school. It's not just for mental disorders either, I have scoliosis and before I went to a non-uniform school I had to have being able to wear non-uniform pants on my IEP so my brace wouldn't push my pants down. Somehow, it took kids in my elementary school (I was allowed to wear other pants in kindergarten) all the way through elementary (5th grade) to notice I wasn't wearing the correct pants, haha!
Thanks for reading :D
